We took it as we have been to lazy. As we have been there on a sunny state holiday, we waited about 20 min in line as a lot of locals used the day to get out of the city. Do not think, it will be that packed on a regular day. You have to pay your tickets first (you get little

We waited 40 minutes to board the funicular. Fortunately we allowed ourselves one hour to reach the restaurant for dinner at 7.30pm. On the way back, we waited 35 minutes to board with half the time queueing outside the station. The views were fantastic no doubt and the

The funicular was 3min ride,expensive,with abit rusts.Had to walk a long steep uphill to reach its lower stop.The view on top was on average.The food there was on average too but its price was dear. Pass it if you dont have enough time in Tbilisi
Great trip but go early as many guests will have the same idea. Stop at the top in the restaurant and enjoy view and food

I have been on several funiculars over the years and the one located in Tbilisi is brilliant! It is a beautiful new funicular and it is quite pleasant to ride. There are great views from the top of the hill. Not pass up a trip on the funicular.

At 15 minutes walk from the Freedom Square, for 5 GEL p.p. a short and steep tram ride will bring you (with one intermediate stop) in around 5 minutes to the top of the mountain. Great views over Tbilisi. Try the restaurant at the left side. Great Georgian pastries, pizza and

It's definitely worth a trip up the funicular whilst in Tbilisi, if for nothing else than the views from the top. The park is beautiful and has something for everyone- fairground rides for the family, and various restaurants and bars. The ride up takes less than 5 minutes, and
The funicular is just a way to get on the Mtatsminda park where you can see the whole Tbilisi, so I recommend to do it. Cons: large queues, too tight cabins.

My son had researched this and was keen to try the park at the tops so we took a long walk up to the base station. There was a short queue, but as the park was only partially open, it wasn't long before we could take the modern funicular to the top. It was very clean and
Great view from the top. We spent an afternoon there and walking around the theme park. The theme park is ok but should go to the restaurant and have a coffee or dessert!

Easy access to the park overlooking the city. Great amusement park on top and good restaurants. The train is spacious and fast. It stops half way up the mountain for those who want to stop at the church. Very convenient and a fun experience.
It cost 3 Lari for ride to the top. there is a big park and attractions for children. Street snack's and very lovely city view...

Now this was fun! A train /funicular going up and down a mountain! Fun for the whole family. Heated seats in the cars which is a treat for winter times and a smooth magical and comfortable ride! The best of views and it goes slow enough to enable you to enjoy the wonderful
A little slow while you wait to have the funicular come but a lovely view as we went up. Unfortunately we had to take a bus to go back down.
Pleasant way of getting to Mtatsminda. Restaurants, bars and kids entertainment on the top, recommend going in the summer on the weekend!

Visited the place with my kids. March still being cold , the ride was very nice. Even though most of the amusement park was closed due to weather. The funicular ride is interesting for kids. A good thing to do if you are with young kids.
We went up using the cable car, it was midday and unfortunately all park rides were closed. The views of the city were great though, well worth it.

We went up the funicular on our last day after dark. While the lights of the city were nice to see, we would have preferred to go up during the day because the amusement park at the top looked pretty fun, as far as amusement parks go. Great view.
When you visit Tbilisi,leave short time for being here. Climbing the mountain to see all the places you saw. From here it’s possible to see and recognize all the sights. It’s cheap,and short.

We enjoyed our visit. Clean, interesting and pleasantly surprised to find a fairground at the top. It was a quiet day we visited. So managed to get around the park with no queues. Ferris wheel was fun. Kids loved it. Restaurant at the top was fab.

This is a fun park at the top of a cable car which you can take and look over the city. Most things were closed as it was winter but the view was great. We went for morning tea but note there are 2 restaurants and one opens at 12 and the man dining one opens at 1. We went up
The whole city sparkling in front of, it is by far the most amazing view you would get of Tbilisi. If you have a choice, go during night time

This was a spontaneous add on to our sight seeing trip and last day in Tbilisi. It was a cold Monday so no long lines. Incredible panoramic view of Tbilisi from behind the restaurants. Enjoyed a beautiful meal with excellent service in the restaurant! Very reasonable and a must
The best way to get to Mtawminda Pantheon or to Bombora Amusement Park. View is just breathtaking. Working till 4am (one way only)
One of a kind train to see the city on top of the mountain. Only 3 GEL to ride and you will see amazing views.
Tip: get funicular to go up to the top of the hill and use stairs to go down to avoid huge ques and waiting.

There are lots of things to do at the top - there is an amusement park with a big wheel (in case you wanted to go higher!) & plenty of places to eat & drink. The view of the city is amazing - we went late afternoon so managed to see the city view at night too.
The park above is not so attractive but fenicular ride is a must of Tbilisi to do list. Take lowest cabin and seats for best view.

It was my first time to be in a funicular. However, it was a nice experience. The funicular have two stops, you can come down in the first stop to view the old church and graves. And then go back to go further up on the mountain with the funicular where you will reach the
A historic yet modernised funicular that brings you up the hill to a stunning view. Try Funicular Restaurant as well! The ride is inexpensive.

The place must be fantastic during the day and during the warmer months. On a freezing January night it was empty of people. Quite a few of the attractions were open with people attending them and the image was rather sad. However, the view of the city was AMAZING.
A cool experience travelling up the mountain with a stop in the middle of nowhere :-) upper station is renovated, with a great view and restaurant

Visited the furnicular for the first time. People managing the place very helpful. Great view of the city from the top. At the top there is a contact zoo, games and some restaurants. You can even stop in the middle to visit the Mtatsminda Pantheon.

This is a fun thing to do with kids to see the city from an interesting angle. It has a neat cable drawn system that really entertained my 5 year old. It was a great way to get to the pantheon and the park at the top of the mountain. A unique experience!

We love the ambiance especially the trees all around the park. The whole gang will surely enjoy the place and the food in the funicular complex were the best especially the khachapurri and ponchik ❤️❤️❤️

Cheap and great way to get up the mountain overlooking the city... the funicular is modern and quick. Wonderful views from the top where you can walk through the park or see to the snow capped mountains in the distance and across the whole of the city of Tbilisi. Another

many people have written about the Funicular but I would like to mention an interesting thing I came across while waiting at the station waiting to go up the mountain. On the walls of the staion there was an exibition of pictures to celebrate the 80th year since the opening of

Great views from the top. Lovely ride. Helpful staff. 3 restaurants at the top station which was nice for a cold evening. recommend doing this activity at night as the view is fantastic with the lights in the city below
This was a nice trip. You should go down to get the best view. A central location as you arrive to visit central Tbilisi.

I was not sure what to expect , a funicular, a park, a restaurant. Each of the three wagons can take 16 to 22 people , sitting and standing. The cynical goes between pine trees and climbs above the city clouds. Spectacular view , and indeed if choose to put more money on the

The funicular with its modern cars runs regularly. Our aim was to have dinner in the restaurant at the top to see the city illuminated below. We were earlier than planned so strolled around the amusement park which, on a cold, grey, winter evening was rather quiet. The
Worth a visit though queues can be long. The park at the top is largely closed on winter evenings which is a bit of a shame but there are great views across the city.

We walked our way from Rustaveli avenue to the lower station of Funicular. It’s actually not that hard as long as you have Google maps with you and a lot of energy to do walking. You need to purchase a special card for the Funicular ride. The good thing about it is that for one

Super place but workers on the funicular ticketing and the funicular trip are quite aggressive and unwelcoming.The lady working at the tickets window was lashing out at the tourists who asked her normal questions and she knew English but was answering in Georgian.

This is something a little bit different and is a convenient way of getting to the park at the top. The park itself isn't too exciting but the views out over Tbilisi make the trip up the top worthwhile.
The trip up the hill in the tram is gives a good view of the city of Tbilisi. Up the hill you have some attractions like Giant wheel and some games. It has a good view of the Tbilisi city.
Nice place to view at Tbilisi. We were in the winter and only few people was there. Some of the places was closed.
Great view over Tbilisi, Trinity Church and the whole city. There are great views opening when moving down at night.

Must visit place for every tourist. Wonderful view of Tiblisi, safe and efficient. This is truly the most beautiful part of Tbilisi and gives excellent panoramic views on the city. On the top there is an amusement park, great for kids and families to relax. And there are the
This is a very nice experience if you want to have a stroll well above the city. It has some amusement options for children and a nice cafe where you can have lunch with a great view of the city
A steep climb up the hill with a good funicular. On the top a very good restaurant. Beautiful surroundings.
Worth the ride but unfortunately the day we visited it was raining. When we arrived at the top everything was closed to our disappointment.

I took a ride on funicular because of good reviews but the ride on the ropeway was more exciting and cheaper. I still enjoyed the scenery on top of the mountain but I would suggest taking the bus uphill because the road was fascinating and worth taking
I think this is the best place to watch a beautiful view of TBILISI .Dont forget to try AMAZING FUNICULAR .
I Have travelled alone lately in the evening and drivers arrange kind of small party into a cabin, it was really fun. Cool view from the top especially in the night.
Knowing the reason why it was built was actually interesting. I hope to try again soon, the view on top was amazing
This is a must try activity in Georgia , its a funicular ropeway which takes you to the top for the magnificent view of the city.
Very good and is a must but I you have to get a non refundable tourist card. Views from top are impressive and was better than the cable car

The funicular leading up to Mtatsminda Park is a both a convenient means ot transport uphill and an architectural curiosity. It is easily accessible and inexpensive and provides a beautiful way to view and enjoy Tblissi from high above the city. It leads up to Mtatsminda park
Really fab to do this ride,don't go on the weekends as the line up is massive,you can get off half way up to go and see the church on the hill side then hope back on later.

Good place to walk with children, especially during hot summer days. You can try to taste restaurant or face Funicular, but it is quite hard to find place during day and evening time. Best place to watch on city if you are a guest, mostly at evening time at sundown, if snow

the trip up the funicular gives great views of tbilisi, the river, bridges, churches, the presidents palace and the home of Ivanshvili, the oligarch. At the top is a nice restaurant to sit outdoors and enjoy the scenic views

Nice place and view over Tbilisi, its for teenagers rather than my wife and I even though we spent long time walking and as it was like a beautiful garden over the top. There are few food cafes or canteen as well as a five stars restaurant looking at Tbilisi.

A wide range of cakes and deserts. The best was Ponchiki filled with vanilla cream. Also the Idealy cake was really good. Éclair was medium quality, A bit dry. The view is excellent, and a wide area for kids to play. Do not miss the cable car.
If you go to Mtatsminda it is nessesary to try ponchiki - kind of cake in restoraunt on top! It is something...
It is worth a ride on the funicular railway to see the view from the top and to visit the church on the way down. It is very popular with locals at weekends so would suggest midweek if possible.

Your Tbilisi trip would not be complete without a visit to Mtatsminda Park which is at the top of this Funicular Railway. For 8 Gel roundtrip fee, you can go up and down by riding the funicular with fantastic views of th city.

Well worth a go. It is a steep walk from the main street, though, for about 10-15 min, but then you can relax in the Cabin with a great view of the town. The view gets even better when you reach the top. You’ll need a card to charge with the fee; we got ours from the Hotel, but

Fairly new and fast way to climb up the mountain. To ride it, you have to buy an extra card and then you can use this card for various attractions in the fun park. Train ride is around 5-10 minutes, with a brief stop in the middle of the route. We went up there just before the
Good service, although long waiting time for going up due to high load of travellers. The return way was much smoother.

Took the funicular up to the restaurant and it was worth it. A very steep but safe climb up and the views were spectacular of Tbilisi and the restaurant was elegant, reasonably priced and tasty with live music taht was not too loud.
A comparatively long ride with great dynamic views of Tbilisi. Well worth the money, especially if you take the front seat.

The Virgin on top looked like Chrost The Redeemer in Rio from afar, but turned out much smaller and not easy to see from the top of the funicular. You cannot walk down in front and get a proper view as in Rio. The walk down was the best part, strolling through narrow streets

It is a must to be done during your trip in Tbilisi. Enjoy the old railway cab, nowaday modern and confortable to clinb the Mtatsminda hill and to get in the park where you can have a rest, nice walk and if you have babies, a lot of various actrations

Is it really necessary for people being paid to run a tourist operation to be rude to tourists who make a mistake? We, stupidly, thought that you had to change cars at the mid point to go to the top but ended up at the bottom again. The car operator went out of his way to try
Very special view over Tbilisi în The sunset. We Travel up with The tele ca în and going down by foto. A very nice experience
Nicely designed. No doubt that this is one of the tourist attractions and must try. Food station are everywhere and fun place
The ride is interesting the view from the hill is also good.The park ideal for kids.You can enjoy the ride.
Excellent views from each of the 3 carriages, but probably the best at the very front. The cars are clean and well maintained and a great way to get to the top.

We came down the Funicular from the park. It was rather fun ride I must say. Coming down whilst sitting in the front row is quite an experience. We really enjoyed it. The view whilst coming down is spectacular too. It was really really fun ride and recommend people to do it
Do this only if you have never done a funicular ride. The ride lasts just a few minutes and the view is mostly hidden by lush trees .

This is must do in Tbilisi as Funicular itself is a very cool mechanism. Two wagons, one pulling other. But the viewpoint on the top ... mm that's the best view of Tbilisi and that's what you should try at evenings.
There is alot of people on a sunday late morning, but the ride is cheap and very short. The best way to go up to see the views
Great ride to the top. Pls check timing as they were closed from 4 to 6 when we visited and had to wait for an hour outside.

Went twice.. first during the day (went on the big wheel in the park for even greater views 5GEL) and had nice lunch with views at the terrace restaurant. Then was told the best time is to go is evening so went again, this time eating at the Chela restaurant with vast city light

You have to pay 2 Gel for a card,even if you only want to go once.And then you pay for the ticket. Think of it as a means to getting to the top and you won’t be disappointed. Even when the queues are not big outside they appear to fill the cars,including people standing, before

Yup the Funicular is definitely a thing to go in Tbilisi. A bit of queuing to get there but once you are in is very beautiful the way the Tbilisi open up: old building appearing next to modern ones, the river and the mountains that surround the city itself. Definitely you start

The staff is rude and untrained. There are queues, and half of the passengers ride standing. Good view only from the bottom two places when you looking down the mountain. Costs gel 3 per card and gel 2 per ticket. I recommend to go to the Park by bus, which costs 0.5 gel.
They have amazing restaurant on the top... lovely local food. Also, good place to spend time with kids. Very fresh air on the top...
Take the funicular to reach the Mtatsminda Park. At peak times you may need to stand in the car. Views are good.

We wen there by tram. There are two choices. By taxi or tram. Tram is more traditional and very chip. Even you go there by walk , it is not far from down town. Funicular is an old restaurant. Now it is included 4 restaurants. We pick Georgia cuisine. We reserve it from hotel to

Funicular is very good place to relax and have dun. There you can find attractions, cafes, restaurants, bars and etc. Funicular must be seen if you are tourist. I would recommend to sit on the Eye, bexause it has spectacular view.

The funicular is a great way to get from Tbilisi town to the entertainment park on top. However we walked from the fortress to the entertainment park (about 3km, 1,5hours) and to get down, the waiting line was long and if you want to get out to visit the pantheon you have to pay
It is like a park if you go up.. But the journey in the sloppy train is really amazing. The evening time is good as it won't be much hot.Kids can enjoy lot.

It's a fun way to spend the day. We took a taxi to Mtatsminda Park which offers beautiful views and many things to do. Then we took the funicular down. We had to stay standing because it was overloaded with people. Going down just takes a minute.

In my opinion, this place is a must visit if u r in Tbilisi, specially if u r with kids or teenagers. The view from the top is spectacular. There are so many rides that u can enjoy with the kids. The place at the top is very beautiful and worth visiting.

The Funicular is very clean and provides lovely views of Tbilisi. The Funicular requires a card - it costs 2.5 Gel, that you load up with credit in advance and then use for the Funicular and also for the amusements at the top - they do not accept cash on these rides. Note:
It takes very short time and money, so everyone should do it. You get nice views from "above" (I went with dark and was really nice) and you can go beside "mother Georgia" statue.
Nice to go to the top and check, not that exciting, can skip if you have very little time and had visited other european countries in this type of train.
I wouldn't want to walk to the top. The is a fully refurbished modern funicular that whips you to the top of the mountain and a clean well maintained carriage. Great views of the city.

To get up it is 2GEL for a card and 2GEL per passenger per direction, so up down is 4GEL. Babies ride free. People are most likely to give up their seats to mommies carrying babies. The amusement rides do not take cash, so you will need to charge your card to enjoy them. Also
The ride in the Funicular brings you to the theme park the ride itself however allready is worth the trip

Great location on Mtatsminda mountain the highest place in Tbilisi where is the Tv tower is located. It has a playing park for both adults and children. Up there many restaurants and cafes are available.

If you really like funicular railways then take this ride if not it's pretty pointless. At the top there are some second rate amusements and stands selling a poor selection of food and drink. When we went up the restaurant sign said closed. It was something to do for an hour but
Nice and cheap way to get a view of the city. On the top there is an old amusement park and some restaurants:)
Lovely view the oversee all of Tbilisi. It is worth a visit especial if you have a little walk and meal at the top.
Nice attraction, especially if you’re with children. The view from above is just super. Highly recommended.

The funicalor is a fast and pretty cheap wat to get up the hill to have An amazing view over the city. At night the view is even better with all the lights of the city. On top of the hill there are also two restaurants a normal one and a more high class restaurant. One way price
This is a great way to reach the top of the hill and the restaurant and attractions that are there. A lot faster than the driving alternative

The place was visible from my apartment in Tbilisi so i googled and went there. The 2 way ride was very cheap- about 5 lari. It has a park for kids, a restaurant and few other things at the top. After a long queue, I went up through the tram. The tram stops at one level and

If you ever visit Tbilisi, this place is must see. You take a very nice tram ride to the Mountain Mtatsminda and the view of the city from the tram is astonishing

Is really worth it! Is very cheap... like 5Gel double way. Try to get in the first compartment so you will enjoy the view better. Sometimes it can take a bit to get into the funicular since they don’t go too fast but still you will enjoy the trip and is the easiest way to get to
The Funicular is a must! it is not too expensive and the view of Tbilisi is amazing. We Recommend the restaurant at the Top with a very nice day-trip around the park
Really nice view especially in the evening. Kids will certainly appreciate to play there. It works till late
Not only that the cost is cheap its the scenery and the vibe that the place has. Reaching the top opens your eyes of how amazing the city is.

This is the fastest and least-expensive way to get a great view of Tbilisi. It’s possible to walk to the lower station from the old city (20-25 minutes). Lunch on the veranda at the restaurant at the top was very good, also with a spectacular view.

The Funicular is a quick and scenic way to reach the Mtatsminda Park. 100% recommended for families hoping to get to the funfair and the viewpoints. A card must be bought for 2 GEL and one person goes for 3 GEL. The card is also the funfair card, which you can recharge.

We took the taxi from station square and paid 25 Lari. On the road was an amazing trip. You literally see the whole Tbilisi from top. By the entrance there was no fee. We did not expect that it was an amusement park. The park opens at 11 am. Funicular opens at 12 noon. Food they
This century old funicular offers access to the amusement park above. The history is interesting and the new trains are comfortable despite the lack of A/C
The ride was enjoyable but overcrowded. There was not any ordered queue and you can't always see outside.
A very entertaining place for kids. A nice experience overall. It has a beautiful view of the surrounding places.

We went up just before sunset, the lines were starting to get a bit long but we didn't wait more than 15 minutes. Price is ok. Views from the top were great, enjoy some wine by the ferris wheel while watching the sunset. Great place to visit if you have kids!
funicular is a good attraction :) this is what it was and will be like many years ago. Funicular will take you to the beautiful park 🌲
I strongly recommend Furnicular as a cheap ride 3 lari one way with awesome view! Quick pleasant ride! Much better view during a night!
A good way to reach the theme park up there. U could spend the day upthere with ur kids or date. Nice ride through the mountain. Great view at top.
I did not imagine they would actually hold a global summit there. So I went, not for tourism but for business. I was positively impressed.

At the top of the funicular, there’s a naff little theme park with mini-zoo, bumper cars, Ferris wheel, cafes, and at least one bar that offered “Unlimited Wine for 10 GEL” – that’s $4! One of the best spots atop the plateau, however, was at the eponymous Funicular restaurant
Absolutely nice way to get up! Buying of tickets was easy, no waiting time! Service was nice and polite. Especially coming down on night was offering great views on Tbilisi.
We spend an evening on the terrasse dining with a view over the city. The waiters are very helpful and the food is the best we've had while being in Georgia

You pretty much have to take the Funicular just for the view alone. Plus you can get a respite of that nasty inner city air with a bit a refreshing oxygen. If you have kids, there's a fun little amusement park amongst the pines. The Funicular restaurant is ok - overpriced and
Great ride. See if you can get a seat facing down as you ride. Going up especially the view just opens up as you go up the mountain. View from the top is excellent

Going up with the funicular is certainly something worth doing. There is a huge park up there with a lot of fun things to do and beautiful sights. Make sure to eat in the Funicular restaurant in the entrance

They take 3 lari for each station to person(there is 3 stations) and additional 2 lari God now why for the card. When I asked why should I pay for the card, everyone told they don't know 😆🤨 funny but infuriating. 😏 They over the city is nice but not worth it.
You are paying for the view, but the food and cocktails are of a good standard. Great spot to watch the sunset over Tbilisi.

Most tourist leave city Tbilisi, without visiting this place, i think it must visit place entrance fee is quite cheap like a Dollar , my suggestion is to go to mtastminda by bus or some other transport and come down by funicular

It is a kind of tram that takes you up the mountain where there is Ann amusement park. The park is average but doing this gives you a break from the usual touristy stuff. The view from the top is amazing. Good photo op. The park rides are pretty cheap. Must have at least 2 hours
i travelled there with my family such awesome journey - nice place to visit. once you reach top of the hill big wide park with lot of activities to do for children and adults aswell.

Great way how to explore city "from above". Buy credit for return ticket and observe city from height. We took a taxi from centre to funicular station. it was around 5 lari. For children, there is some mini zoo and theme park. Do not forget to try georgian wine and "pizza" at

great place for friends, family and children. the temperature difference between Tbilisi is 3 , 4 Celsius. and here is a fresh air. so if you have time just go there and have a rest. also there is a perfect restoration. good luck

It’s a must to do when you are in Tbilisi. Very comfortable modern cars that bring you in couple of minutes up the hill. On the way up the views are simply stunning. The funicular has an intermediate stop where you can disembark to visit an old monastery. We didn’t do it,
To get the best views sit in the front coach while going up or down, else you cant really see much. Its a very short ride but quite steep. The interval between rides is 10 - 15 minutes.

nice & well equipped monement ; starting from beka gardens to high mounting ; the rate is very cheap ; 5 min of travelling by cable car ; you can see all city while travelling specially the old town ;
Our family visit this place in summer . Very good landscape and calm area and garden . Big carousel . Good place for family with teenagers .
A very nice attraction in the city of Tbilisi. A great view can be seen during the drive. Reasonable price
The oldest restaurant with the oldest restaurant is the most delicious traditional and European dishes
Don’t consider this in day time hours July August but it’s perfect around 2000 and there’s nice restaurant/bar.

This is a very new and clean funicular train that operates efficiently and smoothly. The staff is friendly and helpful and the train runs frequently. The restaurant at the top is excellent and reasonably priced. Warning: the amusement park at the top is pretty grim. Many

I don't know if there is alternative way to go there except taxi, i'd preferred to walk ; a kind of climbing. It is a short but sharp trip,nice slope! But the carriage well designed,clean,comfy, not pricey, staff are kind. I took it in the night, the top view of the city is
We enjoyed a tasty lunch, view and breeze in the restaurant at the top of the funicular. We did not our the park at the top station of the funicular.

We arrived at 12.30 to be told the funicular would open at 13.00. It's now 13.30 and it still not open. One guy is just repeating the same phrase in English "we open at one" while a colleague is saying in Russian that it's closed for the day. Loads of people milling about and
Nice experience to try on specially at night time, you will see the beauty of Tbilisi and how they glow like gold while you ascend to the Top
Great view. Decent food. Reservation in advance required for the best view. Breathtaking views while claiming up the mountain in the funicukar train.
you can go to funicular by funicular train.on top you can enjoy your food with beautiful view of tbilisi.
Steep hill up from Hero's square but worth the walk (you can taxi it too) great views across Tiblisi so do it at night and plenty of amusements and cafes at the top to hold the interest.
If you want fine dining with a great view, Funicular complex (the second floor) is your place. With live music and good service.food is delicious but it takes time to get served.

We paid for the full house of hop on and off bus on the red, green and blue lines that also included a free boat ride up the river. Nice amusement park for the kids and view was spectacular from the top. We had great food and wine at the restaurant before taking the funicular
Like doing rollercoaster. Bottom to top of mountain by train. Amaizing view. 3 lari per ride. Really cheap
Unexpectedly surprised by how nice the whole area is with the amusement park, the restaurants and walking around was great!

Went up the funicular trainway in the early evening. Excellent views across Tbilisi and it’s surrounds as the sunsets. Had dinner at the Chela Bistro, really good menu and excellent local beers. Nice park to walk around too

We walked up to the funicular through the steep streets near to the entrance. It’s quite a trek in the heat. The pricing was confusing. You need a card which you seem to have no choice but to purchase and then the money is loaded on to it to get through the turn style. Once up
More or less like any other funicular that you may have visited - not worth traveling on as a special trip

I loved this, climbing the mountain with a thing like a train that just climbs the path for you. You can also watch the views or sit for yourself. It was fun, be sure to take the two way ticket, you can also buy one card for two person, and don’t need to pay for two cards. The
Great means of transport to get from the base of the mountain- Old Tbilisi, Sololaki district, to the very top- Mtatsminda Park. The is one more stop in the middle.

The funicular railway is a good way to get views over Tbilisi as the top station is around 770m above sea level. At the top there is the funicular restaurant complex, but also Mtatsminda Park, which is a mix of bars, amusement park and restaurants. From memory it was 3 GEL

When you buy your return ticket what they don’t tell you is that it seems to come with credit, to go on some rides in Mtatsinda Park. At each ride i had to show this card and receive a discount. When we wanted to descend, the unfriendly guy told me i had used all my credit up.

Sunday afternoon and with the sun appearing, our tour guide suggested we take a one way trip on The Funicular up to the top where we had magnificent panoramic views over Tbilisi and surrounds. A really cheap fare of GEL 3/- per person - the Funicular operates 7 days a week
During few minutes journey you can se panorama of Tbilisi. At the top is restaurant in which you can by something to eat or drink. But the best is view from the top.
You will pay 8 gel round trip. It is the best option to arrive at the restaurant complex! Comfortable and fast!
through the tram you can get a good look of the city.the ticket is bit expensive, the park is just ok ,best for kids & u can enjoy the giant wheel & see a gr8 sunset view from the top.

I went up and it was just okay. I did not eat at the restaurant. Sure, the view is good, but there are other, better views of the city. I didn’t go to the amusement park. If I had kids, maybe that would’ve been great.
This is a very convenient and easy way to Mtatsminda Park. Works until late evening though opens late in the morning. You can have a beautiful view from the mountain top as you get there!
At first I was scared because of heights. But when you go at the top of the funicular, you will see a very nice view and will be inside a restaurant.

Cute little ride in the train to the park (3GEL one way). The park at the top has restaurants and bars with traditional food at very good prices - definitely worth a visit. The park should introduce a refund scheme for the cards (2GEL) instead of forcing you to buy something

Nice experience if it's your first time on a fanicular .Great fun for kids on the top with different rides to choose from .View of the city from the top,but not many viewing decks.The resturant at the top seemed popular as many tables were reserved.
We went up in the funicular one evening and watched the sun set over the city. Nice! Good modern facility. Excellent vantage point at the top for photos of the old and new city.
Very nice experience. It's clean and fast and the view is speachless. From the top you can see all Tbilisi.

Funicular is a must I Tblisi . I can only recommend. Spend the afternoon on top of the town. The view from the restaurant is stunning and gives you a good idea of the city structure. (The cakes are also really good)
Of course you can visit this place! The best view of Tbilisi only over there! Park so much relax and good restaurant upstair
For a few lari you can ride to the top and get the best views of Tbilisi. There’s a fun park at the top, but also bars, restaurants etc. It was well worth it and we enjoyed the experience.
Starts with nice ride, amazing view, finger licking food.. what else you look for when you are on leisure.. This place is worth the visit..
Quick way to get from Mtasminda park to the down town. Instructions how to pay are on the photo. It's convenient way to use it. And you can also make photos when going.

The Funicular ride is an experience and reaching the Mtatsminda Park was a journey. The soviet era restaurant is a water-down experience and so is the intimidating TV TOWER. The views of the city and the stepped park are worth looking at.

I mean.. whats to say. Its a tram that goes up hill? If you haven't ever ridden on one of these and you're here sure why not however they do appear to be in most former soviet countries and if we are to compare apples with apples, the Kiev funicular is a little more visually

Lovely outing on a nice day to take the funicular up the hill to Mount Mtatsminda from where you can see the whole of Tbilisi. The view really is fantastic and the ride up very enjoyable, quick and cheap. The park up there is mostly an amusement park for children but still great

Historical station, with very modern and safety train. Not expansive and easyest way to get of Funicular or on Pantheon. Very special place for children and for people who love beautiful views over old city. Enjoy)))
A must see whilst in Tbilisi, the views from the top are fab, the restaurant is great also but take a jacket as it can get cold even on bright sunny days!
This was a wonderful dining and aesthetic experience. The views from the top of the mountain are breathtaking. Once at the restaurant, you must go out on the balcony to have the full experience.
This place is a must visit n has got awesome view of Tbilisi n the park on the top is just mind blowing.
Feels safe and modern, leaves on time. Brings you up to Mtatsminda with amusement park, fancier restaurants and famtastic view Best way to get there.

This is one of the unique rides you can have in a lifetime. The tram travels on a steep slope taking you from Old Tbilisi to Matsminda park.
The station is at a walking distance from old town and Freedom square area. Fairly short ride with nice views. Can get crowded during holidays.

The funicular runs uphill to Matsminda Mountain and back with splendid views of the city as you get to the top. Make sure you get the front seat next to the driver to enjoy your ride or else the experience is like travelling in just another tram. Since there is a ride every 15 –
It's nice to go up the hill, to walk there and have a nice view being above the city but the Ferris Wheel is reconstructed now and it's the main reason to use the funicular to get up there.

Terrible and very very expansive place ! Me and my husband came to Tbilisi to celebrate his birthday ! Hotel concierge told us to come here and it was our worst decision ! At first I would like to mention that interior was very unpleasant, then the menu is very poor and very

The staff were so helpful and the food was only surpassed by the fabulous views of Tbilisi by night, well done the staff of the restaurant for making our Georgia experience memorable for the right things.

This is the shortest way to reach Mtatsminda Amusement park located at the top of hill. This train is very comfortable, however views are not that great when we traveled as it was cloudy and hazy. Front seat before the driver gives much better views. It is great to know that

From there is the best view on the city. It's better to go there at evening and take a look at the night Tbilisi. There are 3 restaurants up there, so you can order food or drink and enjoy your evening.

If I knew what it was I would have not taken this ride and wasted the little money that I did... it is like a tram which goes up and then brings you down ...nothing much to do up there it could be an excitment for the kids

one of my favourite places in tbilisi! beautiful! you have to see the views from there. it's the highest point in tbilisi

Worth Every Penny, a fantastic location to see Tiblisi. The Funicular it self is a pleasant experience, but once you reach the top it just takes your breath away. Lovely cafe on the top worth a Coffee and Cake. Standing beneath the TV Tower is impressive. You've got to go

text.wiki:
Svaneti or Svanetia (Suania in ancient sources; Georgian: სვანეთი Svaneti) is a historic province of Georgia, in the northwestern part of the country. It is inhabited by the Svans, an ethnic subgroup of Georgians.


== Geography ==

Situated on the southern slopes of the central Caucasus Mountains and surrounded by 3,000–5,000 meter peaks, Svaneti is the highest inhabited area in the Caucasus. Four of the 10 highest peaks of the Caucasus are located in the region. The highest mountain in Georgia, Mount Shkhara at 5,201 meters (17,059 feet), is located in the province. Prominent peaks include Tetnuldi (4,974 m / 16,319 ft), Shota Rustaveli (4,960 m / 16,273 ft), Mount Ushba (4,710 m / 15,453 ft), Ailama (4,525 m / 14,842 ft), as well as Lalveri, Latsga and others.
Svaneti has two parts corresponding to two inhabited valleys:

 Upper Svaneti (Zemo Svaneti) on the upper Inguri River; administratively part of Samegrelo-Zemo Svaneti; main town Mestia
Lower Svaneti (Kvemo Svaneti) on the upper Tskhenistsqali River; administratively part of Racha-Lechkhumi and Kvemo Svaneti; main town LentekhiThey are separated by the Svaneti Range which is almost as high as the main Caucasus range. Historical Svaneti also included the Kodori Gorge in the adjoining rebel province of Abkhazia, and part of the adjacent river valleys of Kuban and Baksan north of the crest of the Caucasus. Writing in 1848, Bodenstedt said that Upper Svaneti could only be reached by a difficult footpath which was closed in winter.


=== Landscape ===

The landscape of Svaneti is dominated by mountains that are separated by deep gorges. Most of the region which lies below 1,800 meters (5,904 ft) above sea level is covered by mixed and coniferous forests. The forest zone is made up of tree species such as spruce, fir, beech, oak, and hornbeam. Other species that are less common but may still be found in some areas include chestnut, birch, maple, pine and box. The zone which extends from 1,800 meters to roughly about 3,000 meters (5,904–9,840 ft) above sea level consists of alpine meadows and grasslands. Eternal snows and glaciers take over in areas that are over 3,000 meters above sea level. The region is notable for its glaciers and picturesque summits.  Svaneti's signature peak is probably Mount Ushba which towers over the Inguri Gorge and can be seen from many parts of the region.


=== Climate ===
The climate of Svaneti is humid and is influenced by the air masses coming in from the Black Sea throughout the year.  Average temperatures and precipitation vary considerably with elevation. Annual precipitation ranges between 1000 and 3200 mm (39 and 126 inches). The highest amount of precipitation falls on the Greater Caucasus Mountains. The region is characterized by very heavy snowfall in the winter and avalanches are a frequent occurrence. Snow cover may reach 5 meters (16.4 feet) in some areas. In general, the lowest regions of Svaneti (800–1200 meters / 2624–3936 feet above sea level) are characterized by long, warm summers and relatively cold and snowy winters. Middle altitudes (1200–1800 meters above sea level) experience relatively warm summers and cold winters. Areas above 2000 meters above sea level lie within a zone that experiences short, cool summers (less than 3 months) and long and cold winters. Large parts of Svaneti lie above 3000 meters (9840 feet) above sea level, a zone which does not have a real summer. Due to Svaneti's close proximity to the Black Sea, the region is spared from the extremely cold winter temperatures that are characteristic of high mountains.


== History ==
 

The Svans are usually identified with the Soanes mentioned by Greek geographer Strabo, who placed them more or less in the area still occupied by the modern-day Svans. The province had been a dependency of Colchis, and of its successor kingdom of Lazica (Egrisi) until AD 552, when the Svans took advantage of the Lazic War, repudiated this connection and went over to the Persians. The Byzantines wanted the region, for if they secured its passes, they could prevent Persian raids on the border areas of Lazica. With the end of the war (562), Svanetia again became part of Lazica. Then, the province joined the Kingdom of Abkhazia (John and Adarnase of the Shavliani dynasty, 871–893) to form a unified monarchy which was incorporated into the Kingdom of Georgia in the early 11th century. Svanetia became a duchy (saeristavo) within it, governed by a duke (eristavi). The province’s Orthodox culture flourished particularly during the Georgian “golden age” under Queen Tamar (r. 1184-1213), who was respected almost as goddess by the Svanetians. The legend has it that the duchy was annually visited by Tamar. The Svans had been known as fierce warriors for centuries. Their inflatable war banner was named Lemi (Lion) because of its shape.
The marauding Mongols never reached Svanetia and, for a time, the region became a cultural safe house. Following the final disintegration of the Kingdom of Georgia in the 1460s, fighting broke out for controlling the province. Part of Upper Svanetia formed an independent principality under the Princes Dadeshkeliani, a branch of the Gelovani family, while Lower Svanetia, originally ruled by the Princes Gelovani, was temporarily usurped and subdued by the Mingrelian princes Dadiani. Facing serious internal conflict, Prince Tsioq’ Dadeshkeliani of Svanetia signed a treaty of protectorate with the Russian Empire on November 26, 1833. Difficult to access, the region retained significant autonomy until 1857, when Russia took advantage of the dynastic feud in Svanetia and effectively abolished the principality’s autonomy. In 1875, the Russians toughened their rule by imposing additional taxes. Protests ensued, and Russia deployed troops against the province. Despite having suffered heavy losses, the Russian army units eventually crushed the rebels burning their stronghold Khalde to the ground in 1876.
Part of the Russian governorate of Kutais, Svanetia was divided into two raions (districts) — Mestia (former Sethi) and Lentekhi — under the Soviet rule. The unsuccessful anti-Soviet Svaneti uprising took place in the region in 1921. 

In 1987, avalanches destroyed several homes and killed at least 80, many of them school children. In the aftermath the Central Committee of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union and the Council of Ministers of the Soviet Union passed a decree to resettle some 2,500 families to districts of eastern Georgia (eco-migration to Marneuli, Tetritskaro, Bolnisi, Sagarejo, Gardabani, Dmanisi, Kaspi, Tskaltubo, Khoni, Ozurgeti, and Lanchkhuti rayons). The end of the Soviet Union and subsequent Georgian Civil War created severe socioeconomic problems in the region. While the Svanetian population resisted the unpleasant conditions of the high mountain environment they lived in for centuries, the increasing economic difficulties of the last two decades and frequent natural disasters — floods and landslides as of April 2005 ([1]) have brought about a strong tendency towards migration. The province became a safe haven for criminals threatening local residents and tourists. Large-scale anti-criminal operations carried out by the Georgian Special Forces as of March 2004  resulted in significant improvement of the situation.


== Population ==

The Svans, the indigenous population of Svanetia, are ethnic subgroup of the Georgians. Until the 1930s, Mingrelians and Svans had their own census grouping, but were classified under the broader category of Georgian thereafter. They are Georgian Orthodox Christians, and were Christianized in the 4th-6th centuries. However, some remnants of old paganism have been maintained. Saint George (known as Jgëræg to the locals), a patron saint of Georgia, is the most respected saint. The Svans have retained many of their old traditions, including blood revenge. Their families are small, and the husband is the head of his family. The Svan really respect the older women in families.Typically bilingual, they use both Georgian and their own, unwritten Svan language, which together with the Georgian, Mingrelian, and Laz languages constitute the South Caucasian or Kartvelian language family.


== Culture and tourism ==
Svanetia is known for its architectural treasures and picturesque landscapes. The botany of Svanetia is legendary among travelers. The famous Svanetian tower houses, erected mainly in the 9th-12th centuries, make the region’s villages more attractive. In the province are dozens of Georgian Orthodox churches and various fortified buildings. Architectural monuments of Upper Svanetia are included in a list of UNESCO World Heritage Sites.
Svan songs and dances are notable cultural traditions. Svanetia boasts arguably the most archaic three-part polyphonic singing. Most of their songs are connected to round dances, are performed very loudly and are full of dissonant chords.

text.wiki:
Kutaisi (, Georgian: ქუთაისი [kʰutʰɑisi]) is one of the most ancient cities in the world and the third-most populous city in Georgia, traditionally, second in importance, after the capital city of Tbilisi. Situated 221 kilometres (137 miles) west of Tbilisi, on the Rioni River, it is the capital of the western region of Imereti.
Historically one of the major cities of Georgia, it served as political center of Colchis in the Middle Ages as capital of the Kingdom of Abkhazia and Kingdom of Georgia and later as the capital of the Kingdom of Imereti. From October 2012 to December 2018, Kutaisi briefly was the seat of the Parliament of Georgia as an effort to decentralise the Georgian government.


== History ==
Archaeological evidence indicates that the city functioned as the capital of the Colchis in the sixth to fifth centuries BC. It is believed that, in Argonautica, a Greek epic poem about Jason and the Argonauts and their journey to Colchis, author Apollonius Rhodius considered Kutaisi their final destination as well as the residence of King Aeëtes.
Later, it was capital of the kingdom of Lazica until being occupied briefly by the Arabs. An Arab incursion into western Georgia was repelled by Abkhazians jointly with Lazic and Iberian allies in 736, towards c.786, Leon II won his full independence from Byzantine and transferred his capital to Kutaisi, thus unifying Lazica and Abasgia via a dynastic union. The latter led the unification of the Georgian monarchy in the 11th century.
From 1008 to 1122, Kutaisi served as capital of the united Kingdom of Georgia, and from the 15th century until 1810, it was the capital of the Imeretian Kingdom. In 1508, the city was conquered by Selim I, who was the son of Bayezid II, the sultan of the Ottoman Empire.

During the 17th century, Imeretian kings made many appeals to Russian Empire to help them in their struggle for independence from the Ottomans. All these appeals were ignored as Russia did not want to spoil relations with Turkey. Only in the reign of Catherine the Great, in 1768, were troops of general Gottlieb Heinrich Totleben sent to join the forces of King Heraclius II of Georgia, who hoped to reconquer the Ottoman-held southern Georgian lands, with Russian help. Totleben helped King Solomon I of Imereti to recover his capital, Kutaisi, on August 6, 1770.

Finally, the Russian-Turkish wars ended in 1810 with the annexation of the Imeretian Kingdom by the Russian Empire. The city was the capital of the Kutais Governorate, which included much of west Georgia. In March 1879, the city was the site of a blood libel trial that attracted attention all over Russia; the ten accused Jews were acquitted.Kutaisi was a major industrial center before Georgia's independence on 9 April 1991. Independence was followed by the economic collapse of the country, and, as a result, many inhabitants of Kutaisi have had to work abroad. Small-scale trade prevails among the rest of the population.
In 2011 Mikheil Saakashvili, the president of Georgia, signed a constitutional amendment relocating the parliament to Kutaisi. On 26 May 2012, Saakashvili inaugurated the new Parliament building in Kutaisi. This was done in an effort to decentralise power and shift some political control closer to Abkhazia, although it has been criticised as marginalising the legislature, and also for the demolition of a Soviet War Memorial formerly at the new building's location.


== Geography ==
Kutaisi is located along both banks of the Rioni River. The city lies at an elevation of 125–300 metres (410–984 feet) above sea level. To the east and northeast, Kutaisi is bounded by the Northern Imereti Foothills, to the north by the Samgurali Range, and to the west and the south by the Colchis Plain.


=== Landscape ===
Kutaisi is surrounded by deciduous forests to the northeast and the northwest. The low-lying outskirts of the city have a largely agricultural landscape. The city centre has many gardens and its streets are lined with high, leafy trees. In the springtime, when the snow starts to melt in the nearby mountains, the storming Rioni River in the middle of the city is heard far beyond its banks.


=== Climate ===
Kutaisi has a humid subtropical climate (Cfa) with a well-defined on-shore/monsoonal flow (characteristic of the Colchis Plain) during the autumn and winter months. The summers are generally hot and relatively dry while the winters are wet and cool. Average annual temperature in the city is 14.8 degrees Celsius. January is the coldest month with an average temperature of 5.4 degrees Celsius while August is the hottest month with an average temperature of 24.7 degrees Celsius. The absolute minimum recorded temperature is −17.0 °C and the absolute maximum is 43.1 °C
Average annual precipitation is around 1,500 mm (59.06 in). Rain may fall in every season of the year. The city often experiences heavy, wet snowfall (snowfall of 30 cm/12 inches or more per single snowstorm is not uncommon) in the winter, but the snow cover usually does not last for more than a week. Kutaisi experiences powerful easterly winds in the summer which descend from the nearby mountains.


== Population ==


== Culture ==
Kutaisi has an ancient cultural tradition. Here is a list of the cultural centers in Kutaisi.


=== Museums and other cultural institutions ===
1. Kutaisi State Historical Museum
2. Kutaisi Museum of Sport
3. Kutaisi Museum of Martial Art
4. Museum of Zakaria Paliashvili
5. Kutaisi State Historical Archive
6. Kutaisi State Scientific-Universal Library
7. Akaki Tsereteli State University


=== Theatres and cinema ===
1. Kutaisi Lado Meskhishvili State Academic Theatre
2. Kutaisi Meliton Balanchivadze State Opera House
3. Kutaisi Iakob Gogebashvili State Puppet Theatre
4. Cinema and Entertaining Center “Suliko”
5. Hermann-Wedekind-Jugendtheater


=== Professional unions and public organizations ===
Georgian Writers’ Union
Georgian Painters’ Union
Folk Palace


=== Media ===
Local newspapers include: Kutaisi, Imeretis Moabe, PS, Akhali Gazeti, and Kutaisuri Versia.  Other publications include Chveneburebi, a journal published by the Ministry of Diaspora Issues, and Gantiadi, a scientific journal.
TV: "Rioni"; Radio: "Dzveli Kalaki" (old City)
Also all the republican newspapers, journals and television stations have their representatives in Kutaisi.


== Sport ==
Kutaisi has a great tradition in sports, with many famous sport clubs. FC Torpedo Kutaisi has participated on the highest level of the Soviet Union football league. After Georgia achieved independence, it won many domestic and international titles. RC AIA Kutaisi won the Soviet Championship several times in rugby, and after independence, national championships and cups. The women's football club FC Martve takes part at the 2017–18 UEFA Women's Champions League qualifying round after becoming champion in the Georgia women's football championship in 2016. Kutaisi also has an influential basketball club BC Kutaisi 2010, 2016 Champion of the Georgian Superliga, which plays its home games at the Kutaisi Sport Palas.


== Main sights ==
The landmark of the city is the ruined Bagrati Cathedral, built by Bagrat III, king of Georgia, in the early 11th century. The Gelati Monastery a few km east of the city, is a UNESCO World Heritage Site. One of the famous churches in Georgia is Motsameta monastery. It is named after two saints, brothers David and Constantine. They were the Dukes of Margveti, and were martyred by Arab invaders in the 8th century. Besides the churches, there are many interesting places in Kutaisi, such as: Sataplia Cave, where one can observe footprints of dinosaurs; Geguti Palace, which was one of the residences of Georgian monarchs; "Okros Chardakhi" – Georgian Kings’ Palace; and the Pantheon, where many notable citizens are buried. The Kutaisi Synagogue which was built in 1885 is also an interesting sight.


== Economy ==
Auto Mechanical Plant is located in Kutaisi.
On April 2, 2009, the Georgian economy minister, Lasha Zhvania, announced that an Egypt-based home appliances producer company, Fresh Electric, intends to create a free industrial zone in Kutaisi.


== Transport ==


=== Airport ===
David the Builder Kutaisi International Airport (IATA: KUT, ICAO: UGKO) is an airport located 14 km (8.70 mi) west of Kutaisi. It is one of three international airports currently in operation in Georgia.


=== Railway ===
Kutaisi Rail Terminal has a direct connection with Tbilisi (Central). Line is served by Georgian Railways.


== Local celebrations ==
"Kutaisoba" is the most important holiday in Kutaisi. It is celebrated on the second of May. On this day the population of Kutaisi crowds into the central park, with their children and celebrate together. Some people make masks and there are many kinds of performances, so it is a lot of fun. Also little children sell chamomiles. It is an old tradition, in the past ladies collected money for poor people, so today children also collect money for them.
On this day one can see traditional Georgian dances and you can hear folk music. Also it is an old tradition to go in the forest, which is near Kutaisi. Families barbecue and play games. On this day, people wear traditional clothes, choxa, so you can imagine that you are in past times. Also there is a new tradition of writing lyrics which have been written by writers from Kutaisi and then airplanes throw them from the sky. There is also a competition in different kinds of martial arts.


== Notable natives ==
Aeëtes – King of Kingdom of Colchis
Bagrat III – King of united Kingdom of Georgia in 975–1014
George I – King of united Kingdom of Georgia in 1014–1027
Bagrat IV – King of united Kingdom of Georgia in 1027–1072
George II – King of united Kingdom of Georgia in 1072–1089
David IV – King of united Kingdom of Georgia in 1089–1125
Veriko Anjaparidze – Georgian actress
Revaz Gabriadze – cinematographer, writer, director, production designer
Niko Nikoladze (1843–1928) – Georgian public figure
Meliton Balanchivadze (1862–1937) – Georgian composer
Zakaria Paliashvili (1871–1933) – Georgian composer
Iakob Nikoladze (1876–1951) – Georgian sculptor, designer of the previous state flag of Georgia.
Władysław Raczkiewicz (1885–1947) – first president of the Polish government-in-exile, 1939–1947
Joseph Orbeli (1887–1961) – orientalist
David Kakabadze (1889–1952) – Georgian painter
Victor Dolidze (1890–1933) – Georgian composer
Petre Otskheli (1907–1937) Georgian modernist set and costume designer
Otar Korkia (1923–2005) – Georgian basketball player and coach (Olympic silver medalist as a player and European Champions' Cup winner as a coach)
Dodo Chichinadze (1924–2009) – Georgian actress
Revaz Dzodzuashvili (b. 1945) – Georgian football player, World Cup 1966 bronze medalist
Zurab Sakandelidze (b. 1945) – Georgian basketball player, Olympic champion
Mikheil Korkia (b. 1948) – Georgian basketball player, Olympic champion
Meir Pichhadze (1955–2010) – Israeli painter, Kutaisi native
Tengiz Sulakvelidze (b. 1956) – Georgian football player, played in 1982 FIFA World Cup, Euro 1988 silver medalist
Ramaz Shengelia (1957–2012) – Georgian football player, played in 1982 FIFA World Cup
Maia Chiburdanidze (b. 1961) – the seventh Women's World Chess Champion
Besik Khamashuridze (b. 1977) – Georgian rugby player, won 53 caps, RC Aia Kutaisi player-coach
David Khakhaleishvili (b. 1971) – Olympic champion in Wrestling
Katie Melua (b. 1984) – A Georgian-British singer and songwriter that was born and grew up here.


== International relations ==


=== Twin towns – sister cities ===

Kutaisi is twinned with:


=== Cooperation agreements ===
Kutaisi has cooperation agreements with:
 Kaunas, Lithuania
 Maribor, Slovenia
 Tartu, Estonia


== See also ==
Colchis
Imereti


== References ==


== External links ==
http://www.nkta.org/

text.wiki:
Turtle Lake is a direct English translation of Kus Tba (Georgian: კუს ტბა), a small lake at the outskirts of Tbilisi, the capital of Georgia, so named due to the perceived abundance of turtles living in these places. The other, less frequently used name of this lake is K'ork'i (ქორქის ტბა).


== Overview ==
Turtle Lake is located on the wooded northern slope of Mtatsminda Mount at elevation of 686.7 m above sea level and fed by a small river Varazis-Khevi, a tributary to the Mtkvari (Kura). The area of surface is 0.034 km², while the catchment area is 0.4 km². Maximal depth is 2.6 m.
The Turtle Lake area is designed as a recreational zone and is frequented by the Tbilisians on weekends. It is also a place where festivals and concerts are held. It can be reached either via a road or an aerial tramway leading from Tbilisi's Vake Municipality - this began operating once more in October 2016, is open from 8:00 until 22:00 and costs 1 lari in each direction. West to the lake is the Open Air Museum of Ethnography, a large exhibition of Georgia's folk architecture.


== See also ==
Lisi Lake


== References ==


== External links ==
 Media related to Turtle Lake at Wikimedia Commons
text.quote: Recreational lake providing walking paths, paddle boat rentals & public concerts & festivities.

text.wiki:
Old Tbilisi (Georgian: ძველი თბილისი, dzveli t'bilisi) was an administrative district (raioni) in Tbilisi, capital of Georgia, from 2007 to 2013. Although the term "Old Tbilisi" has long been used to denote a historical part of the city, it was only in 2007 that it became a distinct administrative entity to incorporate several historical neighbourhoods formerly included in the districts of Mtatsminda-Krtsanisi, Isani-Samgori, and Didube-Chughureti. The district was abolished in 2013, with its territories allotted to several other divisions of the capital.
Old Tbilisi is principally centered on what is commonly referred to as the Tbilisi Historic District, which, due to its significant architectural and urban value, as well as the threat to its survival, was previously listed on the World Monuments Watch (1998, 2000, 2002).The district is located on both sides of the Kura River and is dominated by Mount Mtatsminda, Narikala fortress and the Kartlis Deda monument. It chiefly represents a 19th-century urban fabric with largely eclectic architecture which includes the buildings and structures from the 5th to the 20th century. However, most of the pre-19th century city did not survive due to the devastating Persian invasion of 1795. Only survived building is La Residence, Castle in Old Town the only privately owned Castle in Georgia. Once a fortress before the Mongol invasions, it was from the 16th century the residence of the Persian Shah Administrator for eastern Georgia. The district houses a bulk of the tourist attractions in Tbilisi, including churches, museums, sulphur bathhouses, and peculiar wooden houses with open, carved balconies. In the 19th century, the core territory of the modern-day district of Old Tbilisi was tentatively subdivided into ethnic neighborhoods such as Avlabari with its Armenian and Georgian quarters, Alexanderdorf German quarter on the left bank of the Kura River and the Persian Quarter (Said-Abad) on the right bank of the Kura River.
Old Tbilisi has been the centre of a thriving art community with artist Giovanni Vepkhavadze known for specializing in painting many street scenes in the district.


== New Life of Old Tbilisi ==
In 2010, the government of Tbilisi started a program initiated by Mayor Gigi Ugulava. The idea was to renew old and damaged houses and cobbled streets to make Old Tbilisi more attractive for tourists and visitors.


== References ==

Pickard, Robert (ed., 2001), Management of Historic Centres, pp. 93–112, 275–286. Taylor & Francis, ISBN 0-419-23290-7.
Urban Rehabilitation Policy in Tbilisi (Georgia): Document. prep. by the Technical Co-operation and Consultancy Unit, Directorate of Culture and Cultural and Natural Heritage, Council of Europe Publishing, Strasbourg 2002, ISBN 92-871-4944-5.


== External links ==
Old Tbilisi Official Website
(in Georgian) Old Tbilisi. The Government of Tbilisi.
Tbilisi History Museum. Georgian Art Portal.
Old Tbilisi (vintage photos). Georgian Photographical Heritage Research Center.

text.wiki:
Gabriel (Georgian: გაბრიელი, romanized: gabrieli), born Goderdzi Urgebadze (გოდერძი ურგებაძე; 26 August 1929 – 2 November 1995) was a Georgian Orthodox monk venerated for his dedicated monastic life and piety. With many miracles ascribed to him, Gabriel's grave at Mtskheta has attracted an increasing number of pilgrims. The Georgian Orthodox Church officially canonized him as Holy Father St. Gabriel, Confessor and Fool for Christ (წმ. ღირსი მამა გაბრიელი აღმსარებელი-სალოსი), on 20 December 2012.


== Biography ==
Gabriel was born as Goderdzi Urgebadze in Tbilisi in the family of a Communist Party functionary, who was murdered in 1931. After a compulsory service in the Soviet army, he decided to join the monastic life and was tonsured a monk under the name of Gabriel in 1955. He made himself famous by setting fire to a banner depicting Vladimir Lenin during an International Workers' Day parade in downtown Tbilisi in 1965. He was arrested, tried, ruled to be psychotic, and confined to a mental hospital for seven months. An account of this incident was also published in the West, in the Orthodox zine Death to the World in 1994.Gabriel spent much of his later life at the convent of Saint Nino, a nunnery attached to Samtavro Monastery in Mtskheta, an ancient town north of Tbilisi. He died there in 1995 and was buried at the Samtavro churchyard.


== Veneration ==

The monk Gabriel is believed by the Orthodox followers to have possessed powers of healing and prophecy, while his remains are considered to be incorrupt. The oil from a lamp which constantly burned at his tomb in Mtskheta was also considered to have been miraculous. The grave became an increasingly popular site of pilgrimage. In 2012, the Georgian Orthodox Church officially recognized him as a saint. In January 2014, rumors that Gabriel made the promise in a vision to a local nun in Mtskheta that two wishes would supposedly be granted to those who arrived at the tomb just before Orthodox Christmas on 7 January sparked mass pilgrimage to the saint's tomb so as extra police units had to be deployed to control traffic. The church officials and the nun eventually dismissed the rumors as false.The relics of Gabriel were exhumed for reburial into a special crypt within the Samtavro monastery in February 2014. Prior to the reburial, his body was rested at four major Orthodox cathedrals in Georgia, attracting thousands of pilgrims from all over the country.

text.wiki:
Lisi lake (Georgian: ლისის ტბა) is a small lake in the vicinity of Tbilisi, Georgia; belongs to the Kura River valley, home to a large mixed-use development project by the same name. The landscape is rocky and arid with shrub vegetation and plots of steppe. The lake and surrounding area provide a habitat for variety of different species of exotic birds. In addition to various avian species, the area around the lake provides shelter to a variety of animals such as turtles, foxes and hares. The area is well known for the large population of snakes that live in the hillsides around the lake.


== Climate ==
There is a warm, Mediterranean, and reasonably dry climate in Lisi Lake. The annual precipitation is roughly 400 mm (< 20 mm in January, < 40 mm in April, < 40 mm in July, < 30 mm in October), and there are 20 to 30 days with heavy rains per year. There are also 10 to 20 days with snow cover. The mean temperatures are: January /0, April/12, July /23, October /13, and the mean maximum temperature (in July) is 37 degrees celsius.


== Controversy regarding redevelopment ==

Plans are in place for Green Lisi Town, a mixed-use development on the lakefront. Chairman of TBC Bank, Mamuka Khazaradze's Georgian Redevelopment Company is behind the project, while architectural firm Andropogon did the master plan and site design.
Phase One of Green Lisi Town opened in 2011.Current plans for the redevelopment of the area date to 2007, when a group led by Mamuka Khazaradze outbid a group of Israeli investors by offering 182 million USD for 354 hectares of land. Conditions of the deal with the government required Khazaradze's group to spend 30 million USD on public utilities upgrades in the area and on a system to provide badly needed fresh water to the lake. Khazaradze's group balked at the conditions of the deal and ended up, under questionable circumstances, purchasing the land directly from the city for 55 million USD - a savings of 127 million USD from the original bidding against the Israeli group. All requirements to improve the ecology of the local area have been dropped, and the only conditions now in place regarding development in this area is the requirement for yet more for-profit housing.


== See also ==
Turtle Lake, Tbilisi


== External links ==
Lisi Lake to Regain Past Glory, by Nino Patsuria. Georgia Today October 6, 2006.


== References ==

text.wiki:
Rustaveli (Georgian: რუსთაველი) is a station of the Tbilisi Metro on the Akhmeteli–Varketili Line. It is located at Rustaveli square at the northern end of Rustaveli Avenue. The station was opened on 11 January 1966 as part of the first metro line with six stations from Didube to Rustaveli. Located between Tavisuplebis Moedani station and Marjanishvili station, Rustaveli is 60 metres underground (and an escalator length of 120 meters) the deepest station of the Tbilisi metro system.


== See also ==

text.wiki:
Islam in Georgia (Georgian language: ისლამი საქართველოში) was introduced in 654 when an army sent by the Third Caliph of Islam, Uthman, conquered Eastern Georgia and established Muslim rule in Tbilisi.  Currently, Muslims constitute approximately 9.9% of the Georgian population. According to other sources, Muslims constitute 10-11% of Georgia's population.In July 2011, Parliament of Georgia passed new law allowing religious minority groups with “historic ties to Georgia” to register. The draft of the law specifically mentions Islam and four other religious communities.Mosques in Georgia operate under the supervision of the Georgian Muslim Department, established in May 2011. Until then the affairs of Georgia's Muslims had been governed from abroad by the Baku-based Caucasus Muslims Department.In 2010, Turkey and Georgia signed an agreement by which Turkey will provide funding and expertise to rehabilitate three mosques and to rebuild a fourth one in 
Georgia. While Georgia will rehabilitate four Georgian monasteries in Turkey. The Georgia-Turkey agreement will allow the reconstruction of the historical Azize mosque in Batumi, Ajaria demolished in the middle of the last century. Turkey will rehabilitate the mosques at Samtskhe-Javakheti and Akhaltsikhe regions, Kobuleti District, build the Azize mosque burned down in 1940 and restore the Turkish bathhouse in Batumi.


== History ==


=== Emirate of Tbilisi ===

The Arabs first appeared in Georgia in 645. It was not, however, until 735, when they succeeded in establishing their firm control over a large portion of the country. In that year, Marwan II took hold of Tbilisi and much of the neighbouring lands and installed there an Arab emir, who was to be confirmed by the Caliph of Baghdad or, occasionally, by the ostikan of Armīniya.
During the Arab period, Tbilisi (al-Tefelis) grew into a center of trade between the Islamic world and northern Europe. Beyond that, it functioned as a key Arab outpost and a buffer province facing the Byzantine and Khazar dominions. Over time, Tbilisi became largely Muslim.


=== Timurids ===

Between 1386 and 1404, Georgia was subjected to invasions by the armies of Turco-Mongol conqueror Timur, whose vast empire stretched, at its greatest extent, from Central Asia into Anatolia. In the first of at least seven invasions, Timur sacked Georgia's capital, Tbilisi, and captured the king Bagrat V in 1386. In late 1401, Timur invaded the Caucasus once again. The King of Georgia had to sue for peace, and sent his brother with the contributions. Timur was preparing for a major confrontation with the Ottoman dynasty and apparently wished to freeze the currently prevailing situation in Georgia, until he could return to deal with it more decisively and thoroughly at his leisure. Thus, he made peace with George on condition that the king of Georgia supply him with troops.


=== Ottoman Empire and Iranian Period ===

The Safavid dynasty was in constant conflict with the Ottomans over full control and influence in the Caucasus. From the early 16th to the course of the second half of the 18th century, the Safavids had to deal with several independent kingdoms and principalities, as Georgia was not a single state at the time. These entities often followed divergent political courses. Safavid interests were largely directed at Eastern (the kingdoms of Kartli and Kakheti) and Southern (the kingdoms of Samtskhe-Saatabago) Georgia while Western Georgia came under Ottoman influence. These independent kingdoms became vassals of Persia as early as in 1503.

On May 29, 1555, the Safavids and the Ottoman Empire concluded a treaty at Amasya following the Ottoman–Safavid War (1532–55) by which the Caucasus was divided between the two. Western Georgia and the western part of southern Georgia fell to The Ottomans, while Eastern Georgia (comprising the kingdoms of Kartli and Kakheti) and the (largest) eastern part of southern Georgia fell to Safavid Iran. The bulk of Georgia and the region which had historically always been the most dominant stayed therefore in the Iranian sphere. This partition of the Caucasus and therefore including Georgia under Islamic rule was again confirmed in 1639.
In 1703, Vakhtang VI became the ruler of the kingdom of Kartli. In 1716, he adopted Islam and the Safavid ruler confirmed him as King of Kartli. However, at a decisive moment Vakhtang was ordered to discontinue military campaigns, leading Vakhtang to adopt a pro-Russian orientation, though the Russian failed to tender him the promised military aid.
For several centuries, the Georgian kings and aristocrats converted to Islam and served as courtiers to the Iranian Safavid, Afsharid and Qajar dynasties, who ruled them.


== Demographics ==
The Muslims constitute from 9.9% (463,062) to 10-11% of Georgia's population.
There are two major Muslim groups in Georgia. The ethnic Georgian Muslims are Sunni Hanafi and are concentrated in the Autonomous Republic of Adjara of Georgia bordering Turkey. The ethnic Azerbaijani Muslims are predominantly Shia Ithna Ashariyah and are concentrated along the border with Azerbaijan and Armenia. The Chechens of Georgia living in Pankisi Gorge are also of Muslims of the Naqshbandi order.
The Meskhetian Turks, also a Sunni Hanafi group, are the former inhabitants of the Meskheti region of Georgia, along the border with Turkey. They were deported to Central Asia during November 15–25, 1944 by Joseph Stalin and settled within Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan, and Uzbekistan.  Of the 120,000 forcibly deported in cattle-trucks a total of 10,000 perished. Today they are dispersed over a number of other countries of the former Soviet Union. There are 500,000 to 700,000 Meskhetian Turks in exile in Azerbaijan and Central Asia.There are also smaller numbers of Muslims in Georgia belonging to other ethnic groups of the South Caucasus, such as Ossetians, Armenians, and Pontic Greeks (divided between Caucasus Greeks and Turkish speaking Urums). These are mainly descended from Ottoman-era Christian Orthodox converts to Turkish Islam. Many of Georgia's Muslims defined as 'Ottoman' following Lala Mustafa Pasha's Caucasian campaign that led to the Ottoman conquest of Georgia in the 1570s were actually of Armenian or Pontic Greek origin whose ancestors in Eastern Anatolia had adopted Turkish Islam. One prominent example of an Ottoman Muslim from Georgia of Caucasus Greek origin was Resid Mehmed Pasha, who ironically played an important role in suppressing the 1822-33 Greek War of Independence  (see also Greek Muslims and Armenian Muslims).


=== Geographical distribution ===
According to the 2014 Georgian Census, there were 398,677 Muslims in  Georgia, down from 433,784 Muslims according to the 2004 Georgian Census. However, the share of Muslims clearly increased from 9.9 percent in 2004 to 10.7 percent in 2014. The Muslim population lives mainly in rural areas (298,668 people, or about 75% of the total population). 


== Notable Georgian Muslims ==
Aghsartan I of Kakheti - a king of Kakheti in eastern Georgia from 1054 until his death in 1084.
Allahverdi Khan - Iranian Safavid general and statesman of Georgian origin who was Christian and converted to Islam.
George XI of Kartli - a Georgian King who ruled the Kingdom of Kartli and later he became viceroy of Kandahar province.
Kaikhosro of Kartli - a wali of Kartli for the Safavids. He was the nephew of Gurgin Khan.
Memed Abashidze
David XI of Kartli - a Safavid appointed king of Kartli
Jesse of Kakheti - an Iranian Safavid appointed ruler of Kakheti who converted to Islam.
Koca Yusuf Pasha - Grand Vizier of the Ottoman Empire who also served as the governor of Peloponnese.
Simon II of Kartli - an Iranian Safavid appointed king of Kartli
Yirmisekiz Mehmed Çelebi - Georgian Ottoman statesman
Omar al-Shishani - Georgian-born ISIS commander
Jemal Tabidze - Georgian football player


== Gallery ==


== See also ==
Chveneburi

Batumi Mosque


== External links ==
Islam and Islamic Practices in Georgia


== References ==

Came across this in our walk through the old town. The edifice at front was beautifully decorated as are many of the mosques in the region. it sits lovely in its surroundings. Would liked to have had the time to visit inside but sadly pressed for time.

It is a unique district where you can observe all the various confessions to be next to each other. The Mosque has beautiful mosaic and is a must see for sure along with all the curches in the old town
Very old and traditional mosque, going back to the Ottoman days. The surroundings around the mosque is also worth visiting.

Lovely mosque in a hill in Tbilisi with a view of the fortress above and the Persian baths below. Good view from minaret.
it was a nice scene to witness different nationalities comes together for a jumuah or friday congregational prayer,it feels at peace
Constructed centuries ago, but still looks fascinating. It is clean and mystic and moreover, it is located in old tbilisi, where you can discover plenty of other historical buildings and old houses.

All Muslims who happen to be in Tbilisi on a Friday...must go. Location is OK, close to Shardeni street which is very famous in Tbilisi

Located on the far side of Meidan square and walk up a steep hill to enjoying the old Persian balconies and architecture. Brings you to Tbilisi’s only mosque where Sunni and Shia co-exist happily, as told by our free walking tour guide, worth a walk up the hill for the views
It was actually easy to find it even though I couldn't read Russian or Georgian. A little uphill walk. Nice architecture.

We went in a group of 15 and even though it was a Friday we were allowed to visit. Obviously it has been recently renovated. The exterior had some nice gardens and the interior ceramics are beautiful.

The craftsmen of this era were such magicians with the beautiful creative work on the facade of this building. Worth a little look.
